Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The effect of bilingual language exposure on bilingual children's phonological categorization and lexical processing efficiency

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This dissertation research project will examine how language abilities in bilingual children fluctuate as a result of the surrounding language context. Specifically, the investigators will test how exposure to native English, native Spanish, and Spanish-accented English affects the ability of Spanish-English bilingual children to produce and understand English words. The project will expand the current literature on how sounds and words are learned from their environment, and how speech change occurs in both production and perception. The findings will enhance caregivers' and educators' understanding of the impact of the everyday language environments encountered by bilingual children on their language development.

With multilingual schools and families becoming increasingly common in the US, children experience significant fluctuations in their language environments, both at home and at school. Therefore, it is important to understand the impact of the different linguistic environments on children's language development. To understand how language environment affects children's language abilities, the researchers will recruit Spanish-English bilingual children ages 6 to 9 to complete phonological and lexical production and perception tasks in English. Immediately prior to completing these tasks, children will be presented with stories in English, Spanish, or Spanish-accented English. Measures of phonological and lexical processing after each exposure type will be compared. The children will also complete language assessments in English and Spanish for a full language profile. Comparison of exposure effects on production vs. perception as well as comparison of changes at the word (lexical access) and sound (phonological) level will directly illustrate how language exposure affects language ability in bilingual children.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bilingual children are exposed to multiple types of language in their environment including native speech and accented speech. In the US, these children are usually expected to use English to be successful in school. This study examined how exposure to various types of language input affected English sound and word production and perception abilities of school-aged Spanish-English bilingual children. Sixty-eight children (aged 6-9 years-old) participated in a series of experiments where their English production and perception skills were tested after exposure to three types of speech: native English, native Spanish, and Spanish-accented English.

The results indicate that short-term exposure to native Spanish had only subtle effects on the production and perception of children?s English sounds and words. Children broadened the acoustic variation that they were willing to accept for some sounds, and were less likely to co-activate English words in comprehension. However, the accuracy with which they identified words did not differ after exposure to native Spanish as compared to after short-term exposure to native English. During production, words and sounds were not produced differently or more efficiently after exposure to native Spanish speech as compared to exposure to native English speech.

The effect of short-term exposure to Spanish-accented speech was complex. Children were more likely to perceive speech in a more English-like manner after exposure to Spanish-accented English than after exposure to native English speech. Further, children with lower phonological memory skills also produced speech in a more English-like manner after exposure to Spanish-accented English. Children were also less likely to co-activate phonologically similar English and Spanish words when comprehending English words following exposure to Spanish-accented English speech. Despite the differences in online word activation, children were equally accurate at identifying words after accented exposure as they were after native English exposure.

The finding that exposure to native Spanish speech and Spanish-accented English speech affect perception and production of English in different ways, show that Spanish phonology in the context of English words (accented speech) vs. Spanish phonology in the context of Spanish words (native Spanish) affect the developing language system differently. As a result, theories of phonological acquisition should be careful consider the linguistic context of newly learned sounds when considering how bilingual children learn language.

Practically, the findings provide caregivers, teachers, and educators with evidence that exposure accented speech does not affect the ability of children to correctly produce and comprehend words, although, it does lead to short-term changes in how sounds are perceived and produced. In addition, the finding that exposure to accented speech lead to more English-like production and perception can be harnessed to test the feasibility of using accented speech as a potential tool to teach second language phonology.
